name: ad baculum
description: A threat; an illegitimate appeal to force

name: ipse dixit
description: Making an argument based off what an illegitimate source says

name: ad populum
description: An imbalanced appeal to a majority

name: ad hominem
description: Attacking a person instead of their argument

name: bulverism
description: Disregarding an argument based on how the arguer came to hold it

name: tu quoque
description: Dismissing an argument because of an arguer's behavioral consistency

name: chronological snobbery
description: Rejecting/affirming an idea based on how old or new it is

name: ad ignorantiam
description: Arguing a position because there is no evidence against it

name: equivocation
description: Changing the definition of a word in the middle of an argument

name: accent
description: Incorrectly using emphasis

name: amphiboly
description: Improperly using grammar

name: composition
description: Transfering attributes of a part to the whole

name: division
description: Transfering attributes of the whole to a part

name: circular reasoning
description: Secretly assuming what you are trying to prove

name: post hoc ergo propter hoc
description: Arguing that one event caused another based on the idea that one event happened first

name: bifurcation
description: Oversimplifying the choices of a question

name: complex question
description: Designing a question to eliminate possible legitimate responses

name: apriorism
description: Looking at one case and applying the results to the whole

name: reification
description: Giving conceptual abstractions concrete and personal characteristics

name: sweeping generalization
description: Applying a legitimate generalization to a situation where it is no applicable

name: no true scotsman
description: Attempting to protect a claim from counter-arguments by defining terms in a biased way

name: special pleading
description: Applying a standard to your opponent that you don't apply to yourself

name: false analogy
description: Comparing things with similarities that pose no relevance to the conclusion

name: slippery slope
description: Arguing that one action will inevitably lead to an undesireable conclusion, while ignoring other factors that may prevent it

name: faulty appeal to pity
description: Arguing a position on the basis of pity instead of logic

name: mob appeal
description: Attempting to persuade people (usually a group) by using feelings instead of logic

name: irrelevant thesis
description: Attempting to prove an irrelevant conclusion

name: straw man
description: Misrepresenting your opponent's position, then arguing against the misrepresentation

name: elephant hurling
description: Providing a long list of irreleveant information in an attempt to intimidate your opponent

name: question-begging epithet
description: Using biased and/or emotional language to support a conclusion that is logically unproved
